Award.AwardTitle: Travel to Attend the 12th AIAA/ASME Joint Thermophysics and Heat Transfer Conference (Atlanta, GA, USA, June 25-29, 2018)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Thermal Rectification panel will be held at the 12th AIAA/ASME Joint Thermophysics and Heat Transfer Conference, which is a collaboration between AIAA (American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics) and the Heat Transfer Division of ASME (American Society of Mechanical Engineers). Thermal rectification can have a significant impact in many devices that can benefit from this phenomenon, such as current electronics, by improving passive thermal management and allowing for higher performance. Additional technologies
could be developed in the form of thermal devices like thermal switches, diodes, and
regulators, that could be combined to make thermal analogies to electronic circuits for energy,
memory, and communications. These envisioned devices will require a full understanding of thermal rectification.

Thermal rectification is a phenomenon in which thermal transport is dependent on direction along a single axis, analogous to the p and n junction electrical rectifier (or diode) that allows current to flow in one direction, but not in the other under reasonably low forward and reverse bias. Unlike the electrical rectifier, there have been many mechanisms theorized and demonstrated (at least conceptually) that produce a thermally rectifying effect. Observations based on different mechanisms have been documented as early as in the 1930s and saw a significant increase in interested in the recent years. These mechanisms have one characteristic in common in that they require an asymmetry in the system along the rectifying axis. These asymmetries have been of the form of interfaces between dissimilar materials, gravity, surface emissivity properties, temperature dependence of thermal conductivities, and more, although the realistic effect and its magnitude is still a subject of controversy in several of these.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF supported project funded the travel of leading experts in thermal rectification to attend and present a panel discussion on the topic. The panel discussion covered the fundamental mechanisms of thermal rectification, recent experimental measurements, thermal devices, like switches, rectifiers, and other non-linear thermal systems, and the direct applications of these thermal devices. The panelists were invited based on their expertise in the area and were selected from academia and industry. Two of the panel participants were early career. In addition to the panel discussion participants, a graduate student recorded the panel discussion and is working on a manuscript that will be presented at an up-coming heat transfer conference.

 

The panel audience represented academia, industry, and national labs and had interests across all areas covered (fundamentals, devices, and applications). The interest from the audience resulted in excellent discussions about unexplored or lesser explored mechanisms and niche applications in which they may be more applicable. Specifically, at extreme temperatures (cryogenic and very high). This led to a discussion about the focus and direction the research community to be headed with thermal rectification and the applications to thermal devices. This discussion will be detailed in the manuscript and presented at a future conference for other interested parties to read if they were not able to attend.
